instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, S0 rails present, No Power.
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that has no power and is really confusing me. It had no liquid damage, but won't power on. Green light is good. S0 rails are present. I can "hear" the CPU working/on (high pitched noise with very subtle "tick" noises, etc), but I get no fan. My <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is high (3.58v). The fan twitches ever so slightly when charger is connected, but nothing more (no cycling of twitches, just one lone twitch then done).

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.58v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>: 12.55v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>: 12.56v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: 16.78v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.58v (high)
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.34v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 5.01v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>: 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>: 3.31v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>: 5.01v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>: 1.80v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>: 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_PCH</SIGNAL>: 1.05v

Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, S0 rails present, No Power.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, S0 rails present, No Power.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is not present, no (0v). 

After looking at the board a bit more, I think the high pitched whine may be a stuck transistor somewhere and not the CPU being on. The CPU gets slightly warm after a minute or so, but not hot with activity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, S0 rails present, No Power.
threads.message: OK, rechecking some rails, I now do NOT have <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_PCH</SIGNAL>. I did at one point, I'm sure of it. Going to go through the power block diagram again and see what's up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, S0 rails present, No Power.
threads.message:
OK, I have a more fruitful update.

Following the block diagram, my measurements fall off after steps 21:

21: CPUVCCIOS0_EN is 3.25v @ pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7981</RESISTOR> and at pin 3 of <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>.
<SIGNAL>1V05_S0_LDO_EN</SIGNAL> 3.25v at pin 1 of <CHIP>U7780</CHIP>.

22: CPUVCCIOS0_PGOOD is 0V (Pin 9 of <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>)

I get a good 5.08v on pins 13 and 14 of <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>, so it's being powered and it has voltage on the enable pin. I replaced <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and no change (still 0v on pin 9), so it's missing some inputs. Here are my readings for <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>:

pin 1: 0v
2: .2v
3: 3.25v
4: .5v
5: 0v
6: .5v
7: 1.02v
8: 1.045v
9: .05v
10: 1.05v
11: 1.13v
12: 5.6v
13: 5.08v
14: 5.08v
15: .954v
16: 0v

Any help appreciated on where to go from here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, S0 rails present, No Power.
threads.message: Uhm you have 1.05V on pin 10, this means <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> is working fine......PGOOD is pulled down by another rail regulator.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, S0 rails present, No Power.
threads.message: Ok thanks...so should I continue on in the block diagram? I'm out of ideas at the moment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, S0 rails present, No Power.
threads.message: Would the high 3v42 line indicate a possible SMC issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, S0 rails present, No Power.
threads.message: Look at the diagram and see which regulators are connected to <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. One of them will be missing. My bet is on PVCCSA or 1V8S0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, S0 rails present, No Power.
threads.message:
This board is confusing the shit out of me. I don't understand what type of failure I'm looking at (I've been working on boards for 6 months); all of my regulators (<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_AXG_PGOOD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>P1V8S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>P5V3V3_PGOOD</SIGNAL>, CPUVCCIOS0_PGOOD, and <SIGNAL>PVCCSA_PGOOD</SIGNAL>) are measuring .05v, when they should be 3.3v. At <RESISTOR>R7967</RESISTOR>, I get 3.3v on pin 1 and .05v on pin 2 (of course). Resistor measures good. Diode mode reading is within 5% of a known-good board.

All of these regulators seem to be created in different areas (<CHIP>U7400</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7760</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>). I've replaced <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, and the others seem to be working fine. Enables and power voltages to each IC seem fine. For example, I have my enables and vin for <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> (compared to a good board, the measurements are the same), but I get 0v at pin 23 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> (my <SIGNAL>P5V3V3_PGOOD</SIGNAL>). What could be making all of these regulators stay low? I don't detect any shorts or weird things via diode mode compared to a working board.

I'll be sending this one off to be repaired unless you guys have any other ideas. Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, S0 rails present, No Power.
threads.message: Remove one by one <RESISTOR>R7966</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7965</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7964</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R7963</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7962</RESISTOR>..... Remove one resistor and check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> signal, no present?? put back the resistor, remove other resistor and try again....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, S0 rails present, No Power.
threads.message:
Thanks, guys. Aprendiz, I did as you said, but <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> signal never showed up. I'm going to call this one a fail and send it on for repair by more experienced hands! :) 

Thanks guys. I appreciate all the help as usual. :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, S0 rails present, No Power.
threads.message: It can also be pulled low by all voltages monitored by <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>, one of them may be missing.
